Name: install
Info:
`Sudo apt-get install git` for Debian/Ubuntu users

`brew install git` for Mac OS X users with Homebrew installed

`https://git-scm.com/download/win` for Windows user

Name: config
Info:
This configs Git and tells Git who you are
`git config --global user.email "you@example.com"`
`git config --global user.name "Your Name"`

Name: Public Keys
Info: Get public keys so you don't need to login everytime. Get at: https://github.com/settings/ssh for github users

Name: clone
Info:
Use git clone to clone a repository into your local computer folder. Type:

git clone <Insert link here>

You can get the link like in the image here (Highlighted Portion):

Name: commit
Info:
Commits to whatever branch you are in with commend 

`git commit -a -m 'Added new features'`

-a for add, -m for the message you wrote with the commit

Name: checkout -b
Info:
Can be used to create new branch and switch to it at the same time.  

```git checkout -b iss53

Switched to branch "iss53"```

is equivalent to:
``` 
git branch iss53
git checkout iss53```

Name: checkout
Info:
(For making new branch and checkout, type c!git checkout -b)

Used to navigate to other branches. Example of switching to master branch:
`git checkout master`

Name: merge
Info:
Used to merge a sub branch into master branch. Used when code has been reviewed and ready for deployment.
You must be in the master branch to merge the sub branch.

`git merge sub-branch`

Name: branch
Info:
This command is used to create a new branch

`git branch new-branch`

You can also delete an existing branch

`git branch -d new-branch`

Name: status
Info:
Shows status of git. Shows unmerged files etc etc.
Anything that has merge conflicts and hasnâ€™t been resolved is listed as unmerged

`git status`

Name: push
Info:
If you're in master branch and trying to push to master, you can type: 
`git push`

Else, if you're pushing a new branch, you can instead type:

`git push origin <branch name>`

Name: pull
Info:
pulls in changes from whitgit. Advised to always do before pushing as good practice

`git pull`

Name: stash
Info:
The git stash command takes your uncommitted changes (both staged and unstaged), 
saves them away for later use, and then reverts them from your working copy

`git stash`

You can reapply the stash with `git stash pop`, this removes changes from your stash and reapplies them to working copy

Name: add
Info:
Add files to commit.

`git add <file>` to add new file

`git add -u` to add only tracked files (To track files do the command above)
